content: How can I help you today?

I'm not sure where to start. My wife and I have been going through a rough patch because of challenges with our son, and it feels like everything is falling apart. I’m just so overwhelmed and can’t seem to focus on anything anymore.

It sounds like you're carrying so much right now, between the challenges with your son and the strain it's putting on your relationship with your wife. Feeling overwhelmed can make it hard to concentrate. How are you managing to get through each day amidst all this stress?

I don’t feel like I’m managing much at all. I go to work, but I’m just going through the motions, and at home, it feels like I can’t do anything right. My wife and I argue a lot, and I feel like I’m failing as a dad because I can’t help my son. It’s like I’m stuck in a cycle I don’t know how to break.

It sounds like you're feeling stuck and really hard on yourself right now. You're juggling so much—work, your relationship, and concerns for your son—and it’s taking a toll. It shows how deeply you care about your family, even if it doesn't feel like enough to you right now. What do you think keeps that cycle going?

I think it’s the stress and hopelessness. My son’s behavior keeps getting worse, and no matter what my wife and I try, it feels like nothing helps. Then she and I argue because we’re both frustrated and exhausted. It just feels like there’s no break from it all.

It sounds exhausting and disheartening to feel like no matter what you and your wife do, things don’t seem to improve. You’re both trying, but the stress and frustration seem to keep building. What do you wish could be different about how you’re handling all of this right now?

I just wish I knew what to do to actually help my son instead of feeling so hopeless about it. I wish my wife and I could get on the same page instead of arguing all the time—it’s like we’re just taking our frustration out on each other. Mostly, I wish I could feel like I’m doing something right for my family.

It seems like deep down, you really want to feel capable and connected—to help your son, to work with your wife as a team, and to feel like you're making a positive difference for your family. That longing for things to feel right again really highlights how much your family means to you. What do you think it would take to start moving toward even one of those hopes?

It’s hard to say. I guess maybe figuring out how to help my son would be a start, but I don’t even know where to begin with that. It just feels overwhelming, like there’s no clear solution. Honestly, I don’t even know if what we’re doing now is helping or making things worse.

It can feel overwhelming when it seems like solutions are unclear or out of reach, especially when you care so deeply about the outcome. You’re trying to figure out the best way forward for your son, but it’s tough to know what steps will make a difference. What might help you feel a little less stuck or unsure as you think about taking that first step?

Maybe if we could talk to someone who actually knows about this kind of thing—like a professional who works with kids like my son—but honestly, I’m skeptical if it’ll even help. We’ve tried so many things already, and none of it seems to work.

It sounds like you've really put in a lot of effort already, and it's disheartening to feel like nothing has brought the progress you hoped for. Talking to someone who specializes in working with kids could be a fresh way to explore what might work differently—though it’s understandable to feel skeptical after trying so much. What are your thoughts about exploring this option, even with that skepticism?

I’m not sure. I mean, if it could really help my son, I guess it’d be worth a try, but it’s hard to feel hopeful. I don’t want to put in more effort just to feel like we’ve hit another dead end. At the same time, I don’t want to keep feeling stuck and doing nothing either.

It seems like you're torn between not wanting to face more frustration if things don’t work out and not wanting to stay stuck in the same place. On one hand, you’re hesitant; on the other, you clearly care deeply about your son and want to find a way forward. What might make it feel less daunting to explore this step?

Maybe if I knew what to expect or had some idea of how it could actually help, it would feel a little easier to try. I just want to see even a small sign that things could improve—I think that would make a big difference.

Wanting to see even a small sign of improvement makes a lot of sense—it could make that effort feel more worthwhile and give you some hope. Perhaps understanding how a professional could work with you and your family might make taking that step feel less uncertain. What would you need to know or feel ready to move forward with this idea?

I think I’d need to know what kinds of things a professional would actually do to help my son and our family. I’d also want reassurance that this isn’t just going to be more wasted time and energy. If I knew it was really worth trying, I think I could push myself to do it.

It’s understandable that you’d want to feel confident this could truly make a difference before committing your time and energy. You’re trying to be thoughtful and ensure that what you do is meaningful for your son and your family. What would be the best way for you to find out more about what professional support could look like?

Maybe I could ask around for recommendations or do some research about therapists or specialists who work with kids like my son. If I could talk to someone directly or hear from others’ experiences, it might help me decide if it’s worth trying. My wife might have some ideas too since she’s been seeing someone already.

That sounds like a thoughtful approach—asking for recommendations, doing some research, and even having a conversation with your wife about her perspective. It seems like involving her in this process could not only bring some clarity but also help you both feel more on the same page. How do you feel about starting with one of those steps?
